repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
`libcpp.string.npos` maps to `std::npos`, which is wrong and does not compile.

This PR fixes the bug as discussed in #4268 and also adds a few missing `std:::string` members.

I haven't run the test cases myself yet, so CI may fail. If that's the case, I'll fix them later.

comment_data.body:
This documentation suggests that the comments are correct:
https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/string/string/
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,19 +58,23 @@ cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
         size_t length()
         void resize(size_t)
         void resize(size_t, char c)
+        void shrink_to_fit()
         size_t capacity()
         void reserve(size_t)
         void clear()
         bint empty()
-        iterator erase(iterator position)
-        iterator erase(const_iterator position)
-        iterator erase(iterator first, iterator last)
-        iterator erase(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
+        iterator erase(iterator, iterator)
+        iterator erase(iterator)
+        iterator erase(const_iterator, const_iterator)
+        iterator erase(const_iterator)
+        string& erase(size_t, size_t) except +
+        string& erase(size_t) except +
+        string& erase() except +
 
         char& at(size_t) except +
         char& operator[](size_t)
-        char& front()  # C++11
-        char& back()   # C++11
+        char& front()
+        char& back()

comment_data.body: Why did you chose this spelling over the separate `cdef extern` block given in the [ticket](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4268#issue-937625219)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ from libc.string cimport const_char
 
 cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
 
-    size_t npos = -1
+    const size_t npos "std::string::npos"

comment_data.body: They are correct, but to_string is also C++11 and wasn't explicitly marked as such. There may even be more unmarked C++11 features. I'm not sure what your stance on backwards compatibility is, but in 2021, C++11 should be the minimum-supported version in most compilers unless you specify otherwise via compiler flags.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -58,19 +58,23 @@ cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
         size_t length()
         void resize(size_t)
         void resize(size_t, char c)
+        void shrink_to_fit()
         size_t capacity()

         bint empty()
-        iterator erase(iterator position)
-        iterator erase(const_iterator position)
-        iterator erase(iterator first, iterator last)
-        iterator erase(const_iterator first, const_iterator last)
+        iterator erase(iterator, iterator)
+        iterator erase(iterator)
+        iterator erase(const_iterator, const_iterator)
+        iterator erase(const_iterator)
+        string& erase(size_t, size_t) except +
+        string& erase(size_t) except +
+        string& erase() except +
 
         char& at(size_t) except +
         char& operator[](size_t)
-        char& front()  # C++11
-        char& back()   # C++11
+        char& front()
+        char& back()

comment_data.body: Because it's shorter and seems to generate equivalent code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ from libc.string cimport const_char
 
 cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
 
-    size_t npos = -1
+    const size_t npos "std::string::npos"

comment_data.body: Ok, let's keep them out then to avoid the confusing mix of versioned and unversioned entries.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
I would prefer if Cython knew from the declaration that the name uses a different C++ namespace, 1) because why not and 2) because I can't tell in what way C++ namespace handling will change in the future in Cython, so better declare it correctly right now.

Explicit cnames are more of a last-resort way to get what your C(++) compiler wants. We should instead try to give good examples in the declarations that we ship. Users may end up actually reading them as The Right Way To Do It.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ from libc.string cimport const_char
 
 cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
 
-    size_t npos = -1
+    const size_t npos "std::string::npos"

comment_data.body:
1) I think it's nice to allow keyword arguments by naming the arguments â€“ although, admittedly, it doesn't seem very attractive here, but there's still a slight chance that this breaks someone's code out there.
2) if we're changing these anyway, then we should also add `except +` since the allocation may fail.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -175,12 +180,37 @@ cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
         bint operator>= (const char*)
 
 
-    string to_string(int val)
-    string to_string(long val)
-    string to_string (long long val)
-    string to_string (unsigned val)
-    string to_string (unsigned long val)
-    string to_string (unsigned long long val)
-    string to_string (float val)
-    string to_string (double val)
-    string to_string (long double val)
+    string to_string(int)
+    string to_string(long)
+    string to_string(long long)
+    string to_string(unsigned)
+    string to_string(unsigned long)
+    string to_string(unsigned long long)
+    string to_string(float)
+    string to_string(double)
+    string to_string(long double)

comment_data.body: I removed the parameter names for consistency with the rest of the file. I did not add an exception clause, because none of the other functions that may throw an allocation exception have one. Only explicit exceptions such as out_of_range or so are caught here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -175,12 +180,37 @@ cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
         bint operator>= (const char*)
 
 
-    string to_string(int val)
-    string to_string(long val)
-    string to_string (long long val)
-    string to_string (unsigned val)
-    string to_string (unsigned long val)
-    string to_string (unsigned long long val)
-    string to_string (float val)
-    string to_string (double val)
-    string to_string (long double val)

+    string to_string(long)
+    string to_string(long long)
+    string to_string(unsigned)
+    string to_string(unsigned long)
+    string to_string(unsigned long long)
+    string to_string(float)
+    string to_string(double)
+    string to_string(long double)

comment_data.body: Alright, I changed it. I would even prefer if I could declare it as a static member of `std::string`, because that's what it is. But then Cython would translate it as `std::string.npos`, which obviously doesn't work.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ from libc.string cimport const_char
 
 cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
 
-    size_t npos = -1
+    const size_t npos "std::string::npos"

comment_data.body: BTW these `to_string` functions throw a compiler error about ambiguous signatures if you pass a `size_t` without an explicit cast to `unsigned long`. I am not quite sure why that is and it if is a special Cython quirk (probably ambiguity on 64-bit systems between `long` and `int`). To fix that I contemplated adding an explicit `size_t` overload, but ultimately decided against it, because it's not an official overload from the C++ documentation (although it would work). What's your stance on that?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -175,12 +180,37 @@ cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
         bint operator>= (const char*)
 
 
-    string to_string(int val)

-    string to_string (unsigned long long val)
-    string to_string (float val)

-    string to_string (long double val)

+    string to_string(unsigned long long)
+    string to_string(float)

+    string to_string(long double)

comment_data.body:
> I would even prefer if I could declare it as a static member of `std::string`, because that's what it is. But then Cython would translate it as `std::string.npos`, which obviously doesn't work.

Yeah, I had thought about that, too, but that would prevent a direct `cimport`. I think that's a good thing to allow.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ from libc.string cimport const_char
 
 cdef extern from "<string>" namespace "std" nogil:
 
-    size_t npos = -1
+    const size_t npos "std::string::npos"

comment_data.body:
> I did not add an exception clause, because none of the other functions that may throw an allocation exception have one.

They can raise, so they'd better have one for safety.

> To fix that I contemplated adding an explicit `size_t` overload, but ultimately decided against it, because it's not an official overload from the C++ documentation (although it would work). What's your stance on that?

Sounds like a helpful addition. Also `ssize_t`. The declarations are meant to make Cython users happy, not the spec.

comment_data.body:
This doesn't work in Py2. I sometimes write tests like this:
```suggestion
    >>> test_pop_back(b'abc') == b'ab'  or  test_pop_back(b'abc')
    True
```
(Technically, the test would then still succeed if the function call returned `True`, but then, let's assume that we're all honest developers who wouldn't let that pass through a code reviewâ€¦)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -102,6 +102,15 @@ def test_push_back(char *a):
     s.push_back(<char>ord('s'))
     return s.c_str()
 
+def test_pop_back(char *a):
+    """
+    >>> test_pop_back(b'abc')
+    b'ab'

comment_data.body: Ah, ok. I wrote it that way, because it produces a useful error message if the test fails, which `assert True` does not.

Fixed.

(TBH, it doesn't really matter for the test if there is a `b` prefix, but I guess then it wouldn't be compatible with Py3)

commit.message: Correct std::string::npos and add missing members, fixes #4268
Add size_t and ssize_t overloads for to_string()

Add except to methods that may throw bad_alloc

Add missing signatures for resize() and compare()
Add parameter names to all method signatures
Show useful error message if test fails

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Fix std::string::npos and add missing std::string members
